In this problem, you will prove the Parity Principle of Theorem \ref{thm-parity}: the Sprague-Grundy value of any Lumberjack position has the same parity as the total number of edges.
The key idea behind this proof is the following simple observation:
\begin{array}{rcccl} \mbox{even} + \mbox{even} &=& \mbox{odd} + \mbox{odd} &=& \mbox{even} \\ \mbox{even} + \mbox{odd} &=& \mbox{odd} + \mbox{even} &=& \mbox{odd} \\ \\ \mbox{even} \oplus \mbox{even} &=& \mbox{odd} \oplus \mbox{odd} &=& \mbox{even} \\ \mbox{even} \oplus \mbox{odd} &=& \mbox{odd} \oplus \mbox{even} &=& \mbox{odd} \\ \end{array}
Prove that the Parity Principle holds for k-tufts.
Let G be a tree, and let m be the number vertices of degree greater than 2. Use induction on m to prove that the Parity Principle holds for G. You will need to use part (a) during your inductive step.
Use part (b) to prove that if H is a forest, then the Parity Principle holds.
Find the Sprague-Grundy value of this classic movie scene. Then find all of the winning moves.
Prove that the Parity Principle also holds for Green Hackenbush.

The Tuft Principle (Theorem \ref{thm:tuft}) says that we can replace a tuft consisting of paths B_1, B_2, \ldots, B_k with a single path of length B_1 \oplus B_2 \oplus \cdots B_k. Using the proof of Theorem \ref{thm:tuft} as a guide, prove the following Branch Principle:
\item Branch Principle: Let G be a tree rooted at x and let y be a leaf of G. Let H_1 be tree rooted at z with g(H_1)=\ell, and let H_2 be a bamboo stalk of height \ell. Then
g([G_y:H_1]) = g([G_y:H_2]).

Recall that an even cycle is a cycle with an even number of edges, and an odd cycle is a cycle with an odd number of edges. In Green Hackenbush, show that we can simply our fusion process as follows.
An even cycle can be replaced by a single fused vertex.
An odd cycle can be replaced by a single fused vertex with one leaf attached to it.
Proving these two statements requires that you combine three principles. You must mention them all, in order.
